repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Agricultural Research and Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural Research
            and Extension Project for Nepal was unsatisfactory, the
            sustainability was unlikely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, the Bank and the borrower performance
            were both unsatisfactory. The design and preparation of
            these projects must be based on broad-based stakeholder
            participation, especially the project beneficiaries, and
            must reflect national priorities, to help establish full
            borrower ownership. In addition, project preparation should
            include a thorough institutional and organizational analysis
            of potential project agencies, to ensure appropriate project
            implementation arrangements. Major institutional reform and
            the adoption of new management systems require long-term
            support and are only possible when there is broad commitment
            from the borrower. The need for a project coordination unit
            should be carefully assessed on a project by project basis
            to ensure line agencies take full responsibility for project
            implementation. Credit funds should be cancelled judiciously
            in institutional reform projects, and only after it is
            certain they will not be needed. The need for technical
            assistance, especially long term consultancies, must be
            critically assessed, and where it is needed, it must be
            fielded on time, and preferably be grant financed. High
            level training should be undertaken as early as possible in
            the life of a project.

repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Agricultural Research and Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objective is to
            assist the government in improving management and capacity
            in agricultural research and extension services by (a)
            developing location-specific agricultural technology
            resulting from close consultation with farmers; and (b)
            improving the technology delivery system. The project
            consists of two components: agricultural research and
            extension service. The first component will: 1) strengthen
            the agricultural research institutions by improving the
            management information system, priority setting of research
            programs, and monitoring implementation and evaluating
            impact; 2) support human resource development by training
            research scientists, and introduce a results-oriented and
            performance-based reward system; 3) expand on-farm adaptive
            research responsive to farmers needs; and 4) provide
            facilities, infrastructure, and working capital for research
            institutions. The second component will: 1) strengthen the
            extension service by decentralizing to the grass roots level
            and strengthening farmer self-help groups; 2) develop human
            capital by training extension staff, and implement a reward
            system based on results and performance; and 3) provide
            facilities, infrastructure, and working capital for
            individual participants.
